Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 07:21AM sincitydealer wrote: Your Mom's experience sounds much like my Mom's.  The Faslodex just failed my Mom, too, and her TM's are up.  My Mother is quite old and the Xeloda really did a number on her, but it's mild for most people.  Watch out for explosive diarrhea and sores in her mouth and throat.  A lot of people get the hand/foot problem where your hands and feet dry out and crack leaving them quite sore.  If you see any signs of these SE's call the doc before they get out-of-hand.  They can lower the dose.  I never could figure out why they warn you not to touch the pill with your bare hand, but they expect you to swallow it.  There have been many women on this site that have done quite well with Xeloda.  I hope it's the same for your Mother. Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2012 07:05AM - edited Sep 16, 2012 07:26AM by sincitydealer Hi camd, sounds like you definitely need conservatorship over your Mother.  You don't want her signing herself out if she's in a Hospice facility.  Take a look at the link below to see if your Mom is acting like what is described in the article.  My Mom had a bit of dementia and the cancer and treatments exacerbated it.  She did have the symptoms in the link.  I think this terminal agitation/restlessness is more common in people that have mental issues already, and your Mom's alcohol addiction plus her cancer could be contributing to it.  It's hell on the patient and the caregiver.  Ask the Hospice people if your Mom could be experiencing this.  There's things they can do for it. I'm so very sorry you're going through such a hard time.  I just lost my Mom in July.  I know how you feel. Peggy http://www.hospicepatients.org/terminal-agitation.html

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 06:02PM sincitydealer wrote: Oh, Nil.  My heart goes out to you.  If that's you in your Avatar, you are one beautiful girl.  I can't speak to you personally about having BC, but my Mother has it, so my situation is a role reversal of your situation with you and your Mom. According to my Mom's onc, you can live a long time with this disease.  It's not the automatic death sentence it used to be.  There are so many treatments out there now.  It may be painful to live with, but your doctors will help you manage the pain. You will receive a lot of encouragement on this board from women that have lived with this disease for years.  One makes a yearly post on her cancer anniversary.  She's been living with Stage lV for 18 years and living well.  There are also some very young people on this forum.  You might hear from Texasrose.  She's in her late 20's also.  I'm so sorry that this is happening to you at such a young age, but hopefully youth will be on your side to fight this nasty disease. Come to this site often and listen to these wise women.  They will give you some great advice and encouragement.  They've had a lot of experience in dealing with this, and you will hear from many of them.  I hope you feel better soon, after you get over the initial shock. Take care, Peggy

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2010 09:06AM - edited Feb 28, 2010 09:08AM by sincitydealer Yes.  Get your Mom to sign a HIPPA form.  That's what I did with my Mom.  If you don't have a HIPPA form, the doctor can't tell you anything.  He/she will answer any questions you might have in person or on the phone as long as that form is signed.  They don't really volunteer any information, but they will answer any direct questions, so make sure you have a list of your concerns before you make the call.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 03:32PM sincitydealer wrote: I'm not sure if stage lV is being overlooked or simply ignored.  Katie, I think your post was right on the money.  They don't want to look at the dark side of this disease.  They only want to focus on the positive results.  Maybe people need to be shocked into the realization that breast cancer can and will come back on many women.  My mothers bc was just a tiny pea-sized lump 8-years-ago with no node involvment.  She caught it early.  She did everything to keep on top of it, but still it came back.  Early detection is fine, but once you have it you're always waiting for the ax to fall.  They should emphasize that a cure is needed for all stages.  Early detection isn't necessarily going to keep it from coming back. Peggy
Posts.Title: Why do I feel we are being overlooked cmhartley blondiex46

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 06:54PM - edited Sep 27, 2011 06:56PM by sincitydealer Hi ssanie, from one caregiver to another, you're going to have a lot of up and down days with this disease.  Don't beat yourself up because of any negative feelings you might have.  Being a caregiver can be a tough job, but we do it because we love our Moms, and that's as it should be.  You'll look back on this time with her and be so grateful for it.  Along with the bad stuff, it can be a very rewarding time for you.  I wish you many warm and loving days with your Mother.  I know she appreciates everything you do.  I guess I'm not practicing what I preach, but try to take time for yourself, especially at your young age. Peggy

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2015 02:20PM sincitydealer wrote: I'm so sorry your Mom's going through this. I had a similar experience with my Mother for about three weeks before she passed. She insisted she had to go to the bathroom every five minutes, couldn't stand being in bed, and would pick at her sheets. She also did a lot of repetitive motion. I hope this article will help you to figure out what's going on. I know how hard this must be on all of you.   Many families may be surprised when a terminally ill (and usually calm) family member becomes restless or even agitated. The depth of such restlessness or agitation varies from patient to patient. When moods change or personalities seem to change, family members may be completely bewildered and feel helpless: not knowing what to do. It is common knowledge that individuals who are experiencing even minor illnesses may demonstrate mood changes such as irritability, anger, depression and avoid communication with others. When a terminal illness not only initially strikes, but is now nearing the end, patients may experience profound mood changes. Such mood changes are often difficult for family members to "handle." Causes and treatments for restlessness and agitation are well-known among the palliative care professionals who work with the dying on a regular basis. Those who work with the dying know this type of restlessness or agitation almost immediately. However, the public and patient's family may have no idea what is going on and often become quite alarmed at their loved one's condition. What does it look like? Although it varies somewhat in each patient, there are common themes that are seen over and over again. Patients may be too weak to walk or stand, but they insist on getting up from the bed to the chair, or from the chair back to the bed. Whatever position they are in, they complain they are not comfortable and demand to change positions, even if pain is well managed. They may yell out using uncharacteristic language, sometimes angrily accusing others around them. They appear extremely agitated and may not be objective about their own condition. They may be hallucinating, having psychotic episodes and be totally "out of control." At these times, the patient's safety is seriously threatened. Some patients may demand to go to the hospital emergency room, even though there is nothing that can be done for them there. Some patients may insist that the police be called ... that someone unseen is trying to harm them. Some patients may not recognize those around them, confusing them with other people. They may act as if they were living in the past, confronting an old enemy. Just as in all symptoms, other causes must first be ruled out or eliminated. Nurses must make sure that the physician's orders are being followed, that if any other symptoms are not well managed, the physician is contacted or adjustments are made in order to relieve those symptoms. Physicians and nurses must continually re-assess the patient's total overall condition, monitoring every body system's function. Checking vital signs including pain levels is a first step. Is the patient breathing effectively? Is oxygen being given if appropriate for the patient's disease condition? Carefully evaluating, recording and reporting all outward signs must be habitual with those caring for the dying. Any changes must be understood, evaluated and responded to if appropriate. For example, patients experiencing intense pain may become agitated. The initial thought to use sedatives immediately might make sense if one is not thinking clearly: "... the patient is agitated, I'll use a sedative..." However, that may be a very short-sighted and uneducated approach. Why? Because sedating the patient is not the first action to take. One must first determine what other causes might exist. When pain is severe, sedatives will not eliminate agitation! However, relieving the pain eliminates the agitation. On a more basic level, removing a hard object such as a syringe or catheter tubing that may have drifted underneath the patient may be all it takes to relieve the agitation. Common sense must first be applied! The following are examples of questions that nurses and physicians ask themselves as they approach this problem: As the terminally ill near death, body organs and systems begin to fail to a greater and greater degree. Kidneys stop producing as much urine and function poorly, the liver and other organs also start to shut down. Waste products from the cells and tissues of the body begin to build up in the tissue spaces and blood stream. Biological and chemical balance is lost. The pH in the blood and other areas may change dramatically. In many patients, these changes alone may account for restlessness and agitation that may be quite severe. If, and only if, other obvious causes of restlessness and agitation have already been eliminated, then the physician may directly order medications to reduce the restlessness and agitation. In almost all cases, the physician will have written standing orders for certain medications to be given for these conditions. Such medications include anti-anxiety medications such as Lorazepam (Ativan) and Diazepam (Valium) and anti-psychotic medications such as Haloperidol (Haldol), Chlorpromazine HCl (Thorazine) and others. The nurse and physician must be extremely careful not to give a medication that might be contraindicated for the patient's condition. It is not appropriate to give all patients Ativan and Morphine, for example, if they become agitated. It they are in pain, then pain medication is appropriate. If their pain is well-managed and they are still agitated, then the other medications may be applied. Certain disease conditions respond well to these medications while others have an opposite or no effect. Palliative care professionals need to be reading the latest journal articles and research in order to understand when and when not to use these medications. Any nurse or physician who always uses these medications with all patients who are agitated has more to learn about handling these situations. Palliative care varies according to the patient, the disease, the stage of the disease and the exact situation being encountered. Some believe that palliative care is less demanding than say, acute care in the hospital or intensive care. However, that is not the case. Excellent palliative care requires the same degree of professionalism as in other specialties in health care. Constant patient assessment and re-assessment are necessary. Knowledge of the latest treatment modalities and options is a sign of the very best palliative care has to offer. Knowledgeable palliative care professionals will be most effective in managing crisis situations such as terminal agitation. If crisis symptoms are not being well handled by staff at the bedside, it is paramount that the physician be consulted about the best course of action to comfort the patient and relieve his or her distress. Terminal agitation is a hospice crisis and meets the criteria for starting the continuous nursing care level of care. (See Continuous Nursing Care in Hospice).

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2010 05:48PM sincitydealer wrote: Here is the article.  Sure sounds promising. Researchers are hoping they've found a new weapon in the war on breast cancer -- freezing tumors. A new study carried out by researchers from the University of Michigan Comprehensive Cancer Center found that freezing breast tumors helps stop the spread of cancer in mice. A new clinical trial is underway to evaluate this technique for human patients and could potentially lead to improved survival rates over surgery for breast cancer. Breast cancer is the third leading cause of death for women in the U.S. The University of Michigan study, which appears in the "Annals of Surgical Oncology," looked at two different cryoablation [freezing] techniques. Both involved applying a cold probe to a tumor to freeze it. One entailed the rapid freezing of the tumor (in about 30 seconds) and the other involved freezing the tumor more slowly. The results: the benefit from the rapid freezing is more effective and is likely due to changes in the immune system that help to kill the tumor. Freezing with the slower technique appeared to make the immune system not as able to kill the tumor. Both tests were compared to results from mice that underwent surgery to remove the tumors. Researchers found that the mice treated with the rapid freeze had fewer tumors that spread to the lungs and improved survival compared to mice treated with surgery alone or mice treated with the slower freezing. The good news for breast cancer patients is that this freezing technique has the potential to be a powerful treatment tool for the treatment of breast cancer, says lead study author Michael Sabel M.D., associate professor of surgery at the U-M Medical School. An estimated 192,280 Americans will be diagnosed with breast cancer this year and 40,610 who will die from the disease, according to the American Cancer Society. "Cryoablation has strong potential as a treatment for breast cancer," says Dr. Sabel. "Not only does it appear effective in treating the primary tumor with little cosmetic concerns, but it also may stimulate an immune response capable of eradicating any cells that have traveled throughout the body, reducing both local and distant recurrence, similar to giving a breast cancer vaccine." But what researchers also learned is that much of the success relies on the technique used to freeze the tumors, which can have "a significant impact on how the immune system responds," says Dr. Sabel. "The system we use today appears to be ideal for both destroying the tumor within the breast and generating an anti-cancer immune response." Cryoablation has also recently reported improved treatment of prostate cancer, and it has been reported to show promise for kidney patients who are not good candidates for surgery, as well as treatment for a variety of cancers that have spread to the liver and bone. Laurence Wagman, M.D., medical director of the Center for Cancer Treatment and Prevention at St. Joseph Hospital in Orange, California, has used cryoablation for his prostate cancer patients. He found that the freezing of the prostate gland can destroy cancerous cells. "It has been well-known to physicians that extreme temperatures, either hot or cold, can destroy biological tissues," says Dr. Wagman. The University of Michigan researchers are participating in a national clinical trial to evaluate using cryoablation for early stage breast cancer. Participants will undergo rapid freezing of their tumor, and their blood samples will be analyzed to assess changes in their immune system. All participants will be treated three to four weeks later with standard surgery to remove their tumor.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 10:27AM sincitydealer wrote: laasis, sorry you had to join us, but you came to the right place.  My Mom was diagnosed with mets to liver and bone over a year ago.  She had two mets in her liver.  One took up almost half of the right lobe.  They gave her Taxotere, and the tumors were knocked way back.  She has walking issues and is confined to a wheelchair because of the bone mets, but other than that, she's doing okay.  She was put on anti-hormonals after the chemo since she's ER+.  As others have said, find out your Mom's ER/PR status as well as her HER2 status.  There's treatment options other than chemo if your Mom is positive for any of those.  They're hitting her BC hard with chemo right now because of the liver involvement.  If you're living in the U.S. you'll need to have your Mom sign a HIPPA form with each doctor she sees.  That way you'll be able to access all her information. I wish your Mom much success with her treatments.  It's wonderful that she has you to take care of her. Peggy

Posts.Content: May 20, 2011 01:54PM - edited May 20, 2011 03:07PM by sincitydealer Hi EllsJen,  My Mom is ER+ and currently on Faslodex after Tamoxifen and Femara failure.  She had a lot of progression on her January scan and the doc tried Xeloda; however, she couldn't make it through the first round because of SE's.  He then put her on Faslodex, which is another anti-hormonal given by injection once a month.  She feels pretty good on this treatment with no SE's.  That might be an option for your wife if she's been through all the rest of the anti-hormonals.  If not the Faslodex, Xeloda would be a good choice.  It's a chemo pill, so more convenient.  Your wife is much younger than my Mother who is 83, so I doubt she would get the kind of side effects my Mom got. My Mom just had her PET scan last Wednesday, and we'll get the results this coming Wednesday.  I know how you feel.  The waiting is awful. Peggy

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2018 07:37PM - edited Apr 26, 2018 07:45PM by sincitydealer Snowfall, Since you're HER2+ ask your doc about a trial of a drug called Poziotinib. I hear they're having great success with it in HER2 patients. The side effects can be harsh (diarrhea and rash), but you can always ask for a dose reduction if they're not manageable. One member here, Denny123, was on it for only 8 days, and it knocked the cancer way back! Poziotinib is taken in pill form. This would be another arrow in your quiver if the trial you're currently in doesn't help.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2011 04:58PM - edited Oct 18, 2011 05:08PM by sincitydealer My Mom was about 73 when first diagnosed with stage 1 BC.  A lumpectomy and radiation was done and Tamoxifen for 5 years...no chemo.  Seven years later it came back stage lV.  She is now 83 and has done anti-hormonals and 3 different chemos.  They're starting her on Gemzar tomorrow.  All of the chemos have been very tough on her.  Her cancer is in her bones, liver, hilar, and mediastinal lymph nodes.  They are going aggressive with her, but that's the only choice she has other than to do nothing and let nature take its' course. It can be really tricky treating the elderly.  I would think they would consider your Mom's age, stage of BC, and over all general health before deciding which way to go.  It would be ideal if she were ER/PR+ so she could use the more gentle anti-hormonals. If your Mom does have BC, I hope they can use the anti-hormonals.  Chemo can really be rough on the elderly. Peggy

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 02:21PM - edited Nov 17, 2011 03:10PM by sincitydealer Hi dackpat, You're in kinda the same boat as I am.  My 83-year-old Mother was diagnosed with bone and liver mets 2 years ago.  Is your Mom ER/PR+?  Has she been on anti-hormonals, chemo, or any kind of treatment other than pallative?  I asked my Mom's Onc for some kind of prognosis, and he said his best guess is 9 months to a year from now depending on how well she handles the chemo that's left, so that would be around 3 years total since diagnosis.  She's had liver mets the whole time.  It's really a crap shoot as to how long anyone may survive with this disease.  Elderly people have so many comorbid conditions.  If our Moms were younger, I'd say there's lots of treatments out there.  If your Mom is doing no treatment, it probably won't be long.  That's an awfully big mass she has. Peggy

Posts.Content: May 29, 2013 01:46AM - edited May 29, 2013 01:49AM by sincitydealer Hi Judy, My brother-in-law has been diagnosed with MDS (Myelodysplastic Syndrome/Myelodysplasia).  He was diagnosed last December and has been on a drug called Vidaza, but it doesn't seem to be working.  He has to have weekly blood transfusions and is due to receive a bone marrow transplant the first of July.  His donor was found in the bone marrow bank.  They will have to kill off all my brother-in-law's bone marrow and then he will receive the donor marrow which will change his blood type to the donor's blood type, and he'll be getting the donor's DNA.  They tried testing his sister, but she wasn't a match.  Siblings are usually the best candidate.  Thank God for the bone marrow bank, and God bless this donor for volunteering for this procedure.  After the transplant, my brother-in-law will have to spend three months in the hospital and another two or three months in a sterile environment.   There is also an extended member of our family who has the same thing, but the Vidaza is working on her.  She will probably need a bone marrow transplant at some point in time, but she's doing very well right now.  It's pretty unusual to have two members of an extended family with this same disease because I don't think it's all that common, especially since they're not blood related. Robin Roberts, who's on "Good Morning America," has the same thing.  Her Sister was a match, and Robin is doing very well. I hope this helps you some to know what to expect.  If you have any other questions, I'll try to answer them if I can. Peggy

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 10:28PM sincitydealer wrote: My Mother will be 84 in May.  She's had stage lV BC since she was 80.  She's been through some very aggressive treatment.  She's much like you describe your Mother-In-Law.  She's also frail and uses a walker, moving very slowly. My Mother wants any kind of treatment that will keep her alive.  She has mets to the bones, liver, and many lymph nodes.  I'm not sure continuing chemo is for the best, but it's her decision.  She has been through at least four different types of chemo treatments that had to be stopped due to very bad side effects.  The last one, Halaven, was discontinued today, so it's on to something else.  The elderly definitely are at a disadvantage when it comes to chemo, too many co-morbid conditions. Is your Mother-In-Law ER/PR+?  If she is, they will most likely start her off on the anti-hormonals.  There's several of those.   They're much gentler than chemo.  If your MIL is HER+, they can give her Herceptin, also better than chemo. Make sure you get a HIPPA form signed by her to include you, for each doc, medical institution, etc.  You have to get this before they'll talk to you about anything. This won't be an easy battle you're undertaking.  In fact, it will probably be the hardest thing you and she will ever go through.  I wish you and your MIL luck. Peggy

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 11:01PM - edited Feb 6, 2012 11:02PM by sincitydealer Biddy, Mom has the most common kind of BC, and she is ER/PR+.  They were able to use the anti-hormonals on her with the exception of the first treatment which was Taxotere.  They hit it hard because of the liver mets; however, she had to quit because of the SE's, but it was enough to shrink the liver mets.  After they got them knocked back they put her on Femara.  She had already been on Tamoxifen with her first bout of BC.  She was stage I then with no lymph node involvement.  At Stage lV, she went from Femara to Faslodex which also eventually failed.   She had a good quality of life until she blew through all the anti-hormonals.  They do stop working eventually. Your MIL's docs must think she has life threatening organ mets if they're going to start her right out on chemo.  It's either that, or she is ER/PR- and HER2-.  Thats kind of unusual for somebody her age to not be ER/PR+.  Most elderly women are. I'm so sorry you're going through this.  You have a tough road ahead of you caring for both your husband and MIL.  They are so very lucky to have you. Peggy

CoolBreeze, I'm very sorry if you resent my posting on this forum.  I've been posting here since January 2010, and have never had anybody trying to push me onto the Friends and Family forum.  I can't offer much treatment advice, but I certainly thought my moral support might be of some comfort to the women and men here.  Yes, I've posted a blow-by-blow description of what my Mom is going through along with questions to find out what to do when things happen, and there's quite a few people here who seem to be really concerned and more than ready to help with advice.  If you don't want to respond to my postings, then please don't.  That is your choice, and I certainly won't mind.  If you would prefer that I not respond to any of your postings, then I will respect your wishes.
